revision.text:
{{Infobox VG |title = Rendition: Guantanamo |image = Rendition Guantanamo 20090328.jpg |developer = T-Enterprise |publisher = |designer = |engine = |released = Cancelled |genre = [[Action game|Action]] |modes = Unknown |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Xbox 360]] }} '''''Rendition: Guantanamo''''' was a [[video game]] being developed by T-Enterprise, a software company in [[Scotland]]. It had been scheduled for release in late 2009, but was ultimately cancelled. The promotional material used the slogan, "It's time to fight back."<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/06/01/tech/main5054176.shtml Get Ready For Gitmo: The Video Game] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090603061118/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/06/01/tech/main5054176.shtml |date=2009-06-03 }}, ''[[CBS News]]'', June 1, 2009</ref>
Company director Zarrar Chishti, quoted in Scotland's ''[[Sunday Mail (Scotland)|Sunday Mail]]'' said in 2009: "It's been in production for a year and two months. The player start the game with the orange boiler suit, cuffs and ear muffs. There are certain rules we can't break after meeting politicians so we are not making the game too extreme. We have had a lot of hate mail about this, mainly from America, saying things like, 'Don't dare put out a game that shows them killing our soldiers.' But no US or British soldiers get killed in it. The only ones being killed are mercenaries. We have set it in January 2010 because that's when we think the camp will be closed. We are making a statement. We did not want Guantanamo to be forgotten." <ref>[http://www.sundaymail.co.uk/news/scottish-news/2009/05/24/exclusive-ex-prisoner-joins-scots-developers-to-make-guantanamo-game-78057-21385039/ Ex-Prisoner joins Scots developers to make Guantanamo game] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090528214453/http://www.sundaymail.co.uk/news/scottish-news/2009/05/24/exclusive-ex-prisoner-joins-scots-developers-to-make-guantanamo-game-78057-21385039/ |date=2009-05-28 }}, ''[[Sunday Mail (Scotland)|Sunday Mail]]'', May 24, 2009</ref>
== Cancellation == The game was cancelled citing "inaccurate" details posted on various [[websites]] detailing about the game and the "extreme reaction that the game and its popular misconceptions have provoked." Zarrar Chishti, the director at T-Enterprise, wrote an official statement on June 3 regarding the cancellation of Rendition: Guantanamo on the game's official website, which previously showed the teaser trailer for the game. He claims that the main character was not going to be [[Moazzam Begg]], an actual detainee of Guantanamo, but was instead going to be a man named Adam. He also states no [[United States|American]] or [[British Armed Forces|British]] soldiers would be killed, but instead the institution would be run by [[mercenary|mercenaries]].<ref name="WashTimes20090604">Szadkowski, Joseph, [http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/jun/04/veterans-group-rips-gitmo-prison-game/ Vets group rips Gitmo prison video game] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111215175239/http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/jun/04/veterans-group-rips-gitmo-prison-game/ |date=2011-12-15 }}, ''The Washington Times'', June 4, 2009</ref><ref name="OfficialStatement">Chishti, Zarrar, [http://www.renditionthegame.com/ Official Statement Regarding Rendition: Guantanamo] {{Webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5nahm0tSy?url=http://www.renditionthegame.com/ |date=2010-02-16 }}, ''T-Enterprise'', June 3, 2009</ref>
Chishti states "T-Enterprise is against all forms of [[terrorism]] and would never seek to advocate otherwise. Furthermore, Guantanamo was to be a mercenary run institution and so there would have been NO American [[military]] personnel killed within the game. Again, we support the British and American troops that fight the war against terrorism to make the world a safer place and would not make a game that said otherwise."<ref name="OfficialStatement"/>
The game company was also claimed to be working with [[Al-Qaeda]], which Chishti repudiates saying, "Having clarified our position on terrorism, I would now like to refute all suggestions that the game was in any way linked to Al Qaeda. T-Enterprise has never had and would never have a link to Al Qaeda in any way, shape or form."<ref name="OfficialStatement"/>
==See also== *''[[Special Force (Hezbollah)|Special Force]]'' *''[[America's Army]]'' *''[[Under Ash]]'' *''[[Rendition (text adventure game)]]''
==References== <references/>
== External links == *[http://www.renditionthegame.com/ Official Game Website] *[http://www.t-enterprise.co.uk/ T-Enterprise (Developer)] *[http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/2457713/Brit-Moazzam-Begg-who-was-freed-from-Guantanamo-Bay-cashes-in-with-Xbox-game-Rendition-Guantanamo.html Brit freed from Guantanamo cashes in on Xbox], ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' *[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/scienceandtechnology/technology/technologynews/5417221/Guantanamo-the-Xbox-game.html Guantanamo the Xbox game], ''[[Telegraph (newspaper)]]'' *[http://www.mcvuk.com/news/34496/Guantanamo-Bay-Xbox-game-on-the-way Guantanamo Bay: Xbox game on the way] *[http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2009/05/26/escapee-button-rendition-guantanamo/ Escapee button: Rendition Guantanamo], ''Rock, Paper, Shotgun'' *[http://www.gamepolitics.com/2009/05/26/former-detainee-consultant-upcoming-guantanamo-game/ Former detainee consultant upcoming Guantanamo game], ''[[GamePolitics]]'' *[http://videogames.yahoo.com/events/plugged-in/-former-guantanamo-prisoner-lends-experiences-to-new-game/1318417 Former Guantanamo prisoner lends experiences to new game], ''Yahoo! Games''

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox company | name = Straight Right | logo = Straight Right logo.gif | company_slogan = | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | foundation = 2011 | location = [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]] | key_people = | industry = [[Video game industry|Computer and video games]]
[[Interactive entertainment]] | products = [[Video game]]s | revenue = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | homepage = [http://straightright.net/ straightright.net] }} '''Straight Right''' is an Australian independent video game developer located in Melbourne, Australia. They are specializing in [[porting]] games made by other developers to various platforms. ==History== Straight Right's first title, ''[[Shift 2: Unleashed]]'', was developed for [[iOS]], publisher by [[Electronic Arts]] and released on 4 August 2011. It received mixed, but mostly positive reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/ios/shift-2-unleashed|title=Shift 2 Unleashed for iPhone/iPad Reviews - Metacritic|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=19 August 2015}} Their next title was the [[Wii U]] version of ''[[Mass Effect 3|Mass Effect 3: Special Edition]]'', also published by [[Electronic Arts]], which received critical acclaim, scoring 85 out of 100 on review site aggregator [[Metacritic]],{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/wii-u/mass-effect-3-special-edition|title=Mass Effect 3: Special Edition for Wii U Reviews - Metacritic|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=19 August 2015}} was released on 13 November 2012 in North America. On 20 March 2013, it was announced by [[Square Enix]] that the developer will be responsible for ''[[Deus Ex: Human Revolution|Deus Ex: Human Revolution Director's Cut]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/deus-ex-human-revolution-directors-cut-announced-wii-u/|title=Deus Ex: Human Revolution Director's Cut announced for Wii U|publisher=GameRadar|date=20 March 2013|accessdate=19 August 2015}} It received critical acclaim for its improvements to the original game and usage of the GamePad,{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/3/22/4136048/deus-ex-human-revolution-directors-cut-wii-u-pax-east|title=The 'best version' of Deus Ex: Human Revolution features improved graphics, AI, boss battles and may never leave Wii U|author=Brian Crecente|publisher=[[Polygon]]|date=22 March 2013|accessdate=19 August 2015}} scoring 88 out of 100 on [[Metacritic]].{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/wii-u/deus-ex-human-revolution---directors-cut|title=Deus Ex: Human Revolution Director's Cut for Wii U Reviews - Metacritic|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=19 August 2015}} Their most recent project is porting and programming the [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]] and [[Microsoft Windows]] versions of ''ZombiU'', retitled ''[[Zombi (2012 video game)|Zombi]]'', which was originally developed by Ubisoft Montpellier and publisher by [[Ubisoft]]. It received mixed reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-4/zombi|title=Zombi for PlayStation 4 Reviews - Metacritic|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=19 August 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox-one/zombi|title=Zombi for Xbox One Reviews - Metacritic|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=19 August 2015}} ==Games== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Title !Publisher !Genre(s) !Platform(s) |- |[[2011 in video gaming|2011]] |''[[Shift 2: Unleashed]]'' |[[Electronic Arts]] |[[Racing game|Racing]] |[[iOS]] |- |[[2012 in video gaming|2012]] |''[[Mass Effect 3|Mass Effect 3: Special Edition]]'' |[[Electronic Arts]] |[[Action role-playing game|Action role-playing]] |[[Wii U]] |- |[[2013 in video gaming|2013]] |''[[Deus Ex: Human Revolution|Deus Ex: Human Revolution Director's Cut]]'' |[[Square Enix]] |[[Action role-playing game|Action role-playing]], [[first-person shooter]], [[stealth game|stealth]] |[[Wii U]] |- |[[2015 in video gaming|2015]] |''[[ZombiU|Zombi]]'' |[[Ubisoft]] |[[First-person shooter]], [[survival horror]] |[[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]], [[Microsoft Windows]] |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official|http://straightright.net/}} [[Category:Companies based in Melbourne]] [[Category:Companies established in 2011]] [[Category:Privately held companies of Australia]] [[Category:Video game companies of Australia]] [[Category:Video game development companies]]

revision.text:
'''Sven Epiney''' (born on 14 January 1972 in [[Naters]], [[Switzerland]]) is a famous [[Swiss people|Swiss]] TV presenter, radio host and [[Editing|editor]], who works for Swiss national television and radio [[Schweizer Radio und Fernsehen|SRF]]. He speaks [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], [[English language|English]] and [[Italian language|Italian]]. Since [[Eurovision Song Contest 2008|2008]] he has been the [[Swiss German]] commentator for the [[Eurovision Song Contest]]. He was the presenter of [[Miss Switzerland]] 2010.
==External links== *[http://www.svenepiney.ch Sven Epiney Official Website,In German]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Epiney, Sven}} [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Brig District]] [[Category:Swiss television personalities]] [[Category:Swiss-German people]] [[Category:Switzerland in the Eurovision Song Contest]] [[Category:Beauty pageant hosts]]
{{Switzerland-bio-stub}}

{{Other uses|Terp (disambiguation)}}
'''''Terp''''' is music and dance industry [[jargon]] for "dance".
== Etymology == The term is an [[eponym]] for [[Terpsichore]], the Greek [[muse]] of dramatic chorus and dance.<ref name="Variety 2000 Feb 30" /><ref name="Billboard 1949 Oct 8" /> The term, still in use, was more common from the 1930s to the 1970s by dance professionals and music entertainment industry magazines, including ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', which uses the terms "terp" and "terpsichore" (lower case "t"), interchangeably.
: ''[[Ray Hackett|Hackett's]] herd churns out a highly palatable brand of terp tempi, equally appealing to the ear and toe.''<ref name="Billboard 1949 Oct 8" /> : ''I wrote ''Terpsichore in Sneakers'' during the years 1973–78.<ref name="Banes 1987" /> : [Reese LaRue] {{nowrap| ... }} ''known for torrid terpsichore; died Aug. 8, 1985.''<ref name="Kukla 1991" />
== References == {{Reflist|refs=
<ref name="Variety 2000 Feb 30">[https://variety.com/static-pages/slanguage-dictionary/ "Slanguage Dictionary,"] ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', February 23, 2000; {{oclc|44287800}} (retrieved January 30, 2017)</ref>
<ref name="Billboard 1949 Oct 8">[https://books.google.com/books?id=MA4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT17&lpg=PT17 "On The Stand: Ray Hackett,"] by Lee Zhito (1818–1995), ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]],'' October 8, 1949, pg. 18</ref>
<ref name="Banes 1987">''[https://books.google.com/books?id=x0q8Lc5BkvgC&pg=PR11 Terpsichore in Sneakers: Post-Modern Dance,]'' by [[Sally Banes]], [[Wesleyan University Press]] (1987), pg. xi ("Preface"); {{oclc|48139465}}</ref>
<ref name="Kukla 1991">''Swing City: Newark Nightlife, 1925–50,'' by Barbara Joan Kukla (born 1940), [[Temple University Press]] (1991); {{oclc|23386575}}<div style="margin-left:2em">[https://books.google.com/books?id=cbt1NiemfHsC&pg=PA72 "LaRue, Reese,"] pg. 72</ref>
}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Union |<!-- Include all unused fields for future use. See [[template:Infobox Union]] for usage. --> |name= The White Rats |country= United States |affiliation= American Federation of Labor |members= |full_name= |image= Program cover for the 16 March 1915 Masque Ball of the White Rats Actors' Union of America.jpg |caption = Program cover for the 16 March 1915 Masque Ball of the White Rats Actors' Union of America |founded= 1900 |current= |office= New York City |people= |website= |footnotes= |native_name= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= Merged into |merged_into= }}
'''The White Rats''' was a fraternal organization formed by [[vaudeville]] performers, led by [[George Fuller Golden]], as a [[trade union|labor union]] to support the rights of male performers.<ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1901/02/22/108285123.pdf ACTORS GO ON A STRIKE(2) - Members of the "White Rats" Organization Refuse to Play. Every Syndicate Vaudeville House in the Country Said to Be Affected - Object to Paying Comm...<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Women were not allowed to join. The White Rats attempted to combat the monopolistic practices of the United Booking Office (UBO) and the [[Vaudeville Managers Association]] (VMA), groups formed by vaudeville theater managers to keep performers' wages low and control when and where performers were allowed to work. It was based on the [[Grand Order of Water Rats]], a British entertainment industry fraternity and charity.<ref name=autogenerated1>Trav S.D. ''No Applause - Just Throw Money: The Book that Made Vaudeville Famous'' (New York: Faber and Faber, Inc., 2005)</ref> It received a charter from the [[American Federation of Labor]] in 1910.<ref name=autogenerated2>Smith, Bill. ''The Vaudevillians''. (New York: Macmillan Publishing Co., Inc., 1976)</ref> The union staged several strikes but ultimately disbanded.
==Membership== Golden wrote a book about the White Rats, ''My Lady Vaudeville and her White Rats'', which was published in 1909 by the Broadway Publishing Company.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ljINAAAAYAAJ&dq=george+fuller+golden&printsec=frontcover&source=bl&ots=CICZHc2ILp&sig=LR77tjEvpoM7eoL6vQ2nnA6i1XA&hl=en&ei=XdLdSpi9EISGMs_O5MIM&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CAwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=&f=false My Lady Vaudeville and her White rats - Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> This book lists the following members:
* George Fuller Golden, President * [[Ezra Kendall]], Secretary and Treasurer
Directors: {{list-columns|colwidth=20em| * [[David C. Montgomery]] * John L. Rixford * Mark P. Murphy * Junie McCree * [[Fred Stone]] * [[Horace Goldin]] * James F. Dolan * Frank Gardiner * Chas. T. Aldrich * George B. Reno * George Felix * [[Ren Shields]] * George W. Monroe * Sam Morton * Walter Leroy * M.J. Sullivan * [[Nat M. Wills]] * Chas. McDonald * Harry Hayes * Joe Birnes * Harry Luken * [[Eddie Foy, Sr.|Eddie Foy]] * Bobby Gaylor * [[George "Honey Boy" Evans|George Evans]] * Todd Judge * [[Fred Niblo]] }} It only allowed male performers to join.
==Meeting Places== The White Rats met on Twenty-third street in New York City, in a space above Koster & Bial's Music Hall between Broadway and Sixth Avenue. 565
==Strike of 1901== Soon after the White Rats union was formed in 1900, its leadership committee attempted to negotiate with the VMA, led by [[Edward Franklin Albee II|E.F. Albee]] and [[Benjamin Franklin Keith|B.F. Keith]], to reduce or remove a 5% kickback each act was forced to pay in exchange for being booked on the lucrative VMA circuit. After negotiations failed, the White Rats called a strike in February 1901.
The Western States branch of the VMA gave in to the union's demands, and the Eastern branch went without vaudeville for two weeks. Keith and Albee called a meeting with the performers in which they claimed they themselves had been against the 5% commission, and would ask the other members of the VMA to remove it. Albee and Keith also agreed to go on the record in the press as being against the 5% commission if the strike was called off, and they did so.<ref>Samuels, Charles & Louise. ''Once Upon A Stage: The Merry World of Vaudeville''. (New York: Dodd, Mead & Company, 1974)</ref> As a result, the strike was called off, and performers began to sign contracts with the VMA again in order to secure valuable long-term performing contracts.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
==Strike of 1916== The White Rats staged a strike in 1916 to protest poor treatment by vaudeville bookers. In retaliation, Vaudeville managers, led by Albee, created a [[blacklist]] that prevented any known members of the White Rats from working in any of the 10,000 to 15,000 theaters under his control. Performers often couldn't afford to be out of work, or to work at a reduced rate because of suspected union membership, and the strike collapsed within a year. The White Rats disbanded not long thereafter.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070810101042/http://vaudeville.org/index_files/Page400.htm The White Rats page at Vaudeville.org], archived at the Internet Archive's Wayback Machine on August 10, 2007.
